FacilityName: Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC - Albion, NE Facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC is submitting this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations at this Facility.  This electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident, and to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



The Facility is submitting this to reflect a change in Covered Process Operations.  Specifically, the Facility has removed its Stationary Pressure Vessel from service and now retains a Transport Owner/Operator to stage Cargo Tanks as the anhydrous ammonia source for Fertilizer Blending.  Once the anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the Cargo Tank to the Mobile Pipe Reactor, the Cargo Tank leaves the Facility.  All accident prevention elements have been reviewed and/or updated.  



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of agricultural chemical storage and handling, blending, retail sale and distribution.  The covered processes operated at this Facility include:



o    Covered Process 1: Cargo Tank Staging (Anhydrous Ammonia)

o    Covered Process 2: Fertilizer Blending (Ammonium Polyphosphate)



Anhydrous ammonia is transported to this Facility by a Contractor owned and operated Cargo Tank.  The Cargo Tank Operator stages the Cargo Tank at the Facility and remains present to open and close valves, and to implement emergency shutdown procedures if required.  The Cargo Tank is connected to the Mobile Pipe Reactor by transfer hoses.



The Facility hires a Contactor (A.K.A. Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor - IFRC) to transfer and blend anhydrous ammonia with super phosphoric acid and water to

make ammonium polyphosphate (APP) fertilizer.  The APP liquid fertilizer is blended in a Mobile Pipe Reactor (MPR) that is owned and operated by the Contractor.  The APP liquid fertilizer is not subject to the PSM/RMP rules.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case offsite consequence analyses were completed for both covered processes.  The worst case release scenario is the same for the both covered processes because the largest vessel (i.e. a 10,725-gallon Cargo Tank) is common to both covered processes when connected, and the MPR is not capable of storing anhydrous ammonia.  The worst case release scenario assumes that all the content in the largest vessel (i.e. Cargo Tank) is released.   The release scenario consists of the cargo Tank being punctured on the side at the ground level and the release is modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenarios are the same for the two covered processes.  The alternative scenario is a 30-second release from a violent rupture of a 2-inch transfer hose caused by an impact or pull-away during a transfer operation.  This alternative scenario considers active mitigation of the safety equipment (i.e. emergency shutoff and excess flow valves on the Cargo Tank; emergency shutoff valves on the mobile pipe reactor; and backpressure check valve and excess flow valves on the PV side of the transfer hose connection), and operating procedures that the Contractors use to safeguard against releases from ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Operations Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Operations Manager is assisted by other Facility staff, as directed.  The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that Facility Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Accident Prevention Program elements.  The Operations Manager is responsible for managing the Contractors in accordance with

the Facility PSM/RMP Contractor management program.  The Contractors are responsible for training their personnel.  The Cargo Tank Owner/Operator is responsible for maintaining its equipment in accordance with the DOT regulations, and the IFRC Contractor is responsible for the implementation of its OSHA PSM.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility.   The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its LEPC and local fire department.  



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The PSM/RMP implemented by the Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or makes changes to the process. 



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 8 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to this Facility.
